Stories from the Salish Sea: The Kelp Highway

My good friend Chris Morgan narrated a project for Seattle Aquarium focused on the ecology environments around us here in Puget Sound. I can't recommend this series highly enough. The cinematography (and subject matter) are absolutely amazing.

A great place to start is here: https://youtu.be/jg1M4ZdDiY8

The entire series is here: https://salishsea.seattleaquarium.org

Worth a boost if you love the kelp that sustains our marine environments.

Recent discussions here have reminded me of a song that I, or professors I've TA'ed for, often show to our students.

"Mommy let you use your iPad/ You were barely two/ And it did all the things we designed it to do" always gets to me. I had no role in building the current internet; I grew up working class in the Bronx, I didn't even have internet at home until 2002. But I still feel a certain amount of guilt when I look at my students.

title: Pre- KEIO TECHNO-MALL 2022（第2回）「慶應義塾が進める医療ヘルスケア領域のデータベース構築とそれを用いたオープンイノベーションによる事業創出の取り組み」

last_post.content:
興味深い慶応大のヘルスケアイノベーションイベントを見て、参考になりました。

最初に中村先生は明確に日本の高齢者ケア状態を客観的なデータと主観的なデータを組み合わせることによって検討して総合的なヘルスコモンズネットワークモデルを提案しました。このモデルはAIとアルゴリズムを用いて複数なヘルスケア機関と連携してお年寄りの方のために効果的でカスタマイズされたソリューションを提供できるようにできます。心配しているのはデータバイアスなどの課題はあげませんでした。

最後に陣崎先生は「AIホスピタル」のコンセプトについて発表しました。このトークにもいろんな大事なアイデアが説明されて、人材資源が不足している日本でデータを用いて効果的な病院機関が作れるのは必要だと思います。しかしAI倫理はこの活動に大きな影響を与える可能性は高いですので、倫理が最初から研究に盛り込んだ方がいいと思います。

このような研究は日本で行っているのは素晴らしいと思います。このプロジェクトは世界のモデルになれるかもしれませんので、AI倫理が中心的にするべきだと思います

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EuTT7rS_JGU #AI

Next was an informative talk by @PawelAdrjan on global #RemoteWork trends from #Indeed #data at the Digital Futures at #Work Research Centre (Digit). With some thorough caveats at the beginning, this talk nicely reviews where the data appears to show workplace strategy trends settling. Useful for level setting and for #governments, but for organizations this shouldn't influence strategy b/c companies have absolutely no idea what they're doing on #workplace strategy https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KQwmszM8B5U (8/9)

Next was an introduction to #AlanTuringInstitute's #data #justice initiative. This is a good quick summary of the potential harms of #algorithms and data-driven technologies https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HPs1u5aibHM (7/9)

Next was two panel discussions at the #TechPolicyLab's We Robot conference, covering #AI #ethics and #regulation. The panels themselves were great, but a lot of the Q&A was... something https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CeWMlzcc2KE (6/9)

Next was an interesting talk by Steve Tadelis on running an extremely effective ad experiment to increase COVID-19 #vaccination rates at the #MIT Initiative on the Digital #Economy. The effect size here is bonkers, and for the life of me I can't find alternative explanations for how a relatively simple intervention generated such a huge effect. Kudos to the authors! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-0jas3d9Cpg (5/9)

title: Computational Antitrust: Measuring Interlocks in The Life Sciences Industry (Mark Lemley)

last_post.content: Next was a fantastic talk by @marklemley on measuring #board interlocks at #StanfordCodeX's Computational #Antitrust conference. Mapping and analyzing board interlock #networks from publicly company #data seems like a no-brainer for regulators, especially given that much of this activity is illegal! Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kRuOmWbnNp4 (4/9)

Next was an amazing talk by @sarameghanbeery on #ComputerVision for #biodiversity monitoring. The intersection of #CitizenScience, #AIEthics, and partnering with local stakeholders described here is an excellent model for all (also I'm glad it seems that Beery is joining MIT!). Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SDnGCZfBK-w (3/9)

Report back from Twitter filter fuzzing.

What Twitter is blocking

Twitter is filtering links to known Mastodon instances, but still allows direct links to joinmastodon.org. The filtering seems to happen whenever Twitter's WYSIWYG editor recognizes a valid domain name and that domain happens to be a known Mastodon instance.
Twitter also allows linking to shortened URLs of mastodon profiles, but only once. Posting the shortened URL a second time doesn't work, implying there's some backend queue service that's checking the Location header of links and flagging the ones redirecting to Mastodon instances.

How to evade the filters

Email address spam evasion techniques work. Replacing '.' with ' . ' or [.] or [dot] all work.
URI encoding the hostname. Replace at least one of the characters in the hostname with it's URI encoded version (ex: . -> %2E, https://infosec.exchange -> https://infosec%2Eexchange). Browsers are smart enough to URI decode anything you copy/paste into the address bar.
data: URIs. Twitter does not seem to check base64 encoded data: URIs. It is possible to create a data:text/html;base64,... base64 encoded HTML URI which can be copied into the address bar and will render as HTML. While Twitter will not render data: URIs (for obvious reasons), you can still copy/paste them (at your own risk, of course).
Base64. This seems silly, but we could communicate freely on Twitter by simply Base64 encoding our tweets. This could be accomplished via some Chrome extension.

Twitter's anti-Mastodon filtering is clown shoes amateur hour.🤡​

Edit: as many have pointed out, adding a Mastodon link to the alt-text of your background image presumably still works, encoding the link as a QR code works, setting your Location or Display Name to your mastodon handle works. I only tested links to Mastodon instances in tweets.
Edit 2: someone setup a link shortening service that explicitly blocks Twitter from checking the links which seems to be working: https://spacekaren.sucks/
Edit 3: Twitter has now formalized it's Mastodon censorship policy: https://help.twitter.com/en/rules-and-policies/social-platforms-policy
Edit 4: now that I'm trending on HN, I should link to this other researcher on YouTube who did a much more in-depth analysis of Twitter's JavaScript and API requests: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oHg5SJYRHA0&t=1s

#twitter #birbsite #censorship #filtering #evasion #elmo #muskrat

I love Adam Neely's explanations of music theory and what it's like to be a jazz musician struggling to make a living in New York. But I wasn't so sure I liked his actual music. I'd call it electronic fusion jazz, with technically sophisticated rhythmic tricks like quintuplets, and clever harmonies and melodies. But it didn't move me.

This song, Bird on a Wing, actually does:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1fVleqrHF0w

(1/n)

title: The Role of Gender & Inclusion in Development Programming [CID Speaker Series]

last_post.content: Next was an important talk by Muthoni Muriu on developing #gender and #inclusion policies for multinational, mission-driven organizations at #CIDHarvard. Building processes and policies into an organization's #culture and following through when scandals strike or new geographies present a challenge are lessons for all people in #management https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N9uh3YvVDoI (10/12)

title: Are super apps the future of mobile-first Africa? | The Next Wave show S1 Ep6

last_post.content: Next was an exciting discussion on why #SuperApps are emerging in #Africa with Emeka Ajene and Alastair Sussock at #TechCabal. I haven't heard such a coherent discussion of super apps before, and the conversation leaves me increasingly interested in this area of African #tech. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DelrsUkFpEc (9/12)

Next was an intriguing talk by Fang Lee Cooke on bringing the strategic #HR theoretical framework to #GigWork at the Digital Futures at #Work Research Centre (Digit). Gigwork companies are ruthlessly efficient from a myopic perspective here, but connecting the employee view of #employment and development to HR strategy is a nice contribution https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_XxTD_pIfK8 (8/12) #management

Next was an amazing panel on the implications of #ESG shareholder activism with Tara Giunta, Eduardo Gallardo, Peter Michelsen, and Michael Callahan. Universal proxy cards (!), why the current ESG push is different than activism of the past, and how #companies and #boards should plan for this moving forward. This is the next frontier for #PeopleAnalytics IMO. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Of_hpYB8wkU (7/12) #management #business

title: Tech Talk with Barry Friedman: Keeping Personal Data Safe From Law Enforcement

last_post.content: Next was an excellent talk by Barry Friedman on safeguarding personal #data from #LawEnforcement at the #TechPolicyLab. As #police #surveillance increases, this talk explores legal and technical frameworks that can be combined to ensure #privacy while enabling #law enforcement on critical issues. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-0JDzpx3n88 (6/12)

Next was a spicy talk by Damon McCoy on auditing #SocialMedia #platforms at the #MIT Initiative on the Digital #Economy. Getting an independent view of the influence of these platforms is a massive undertaking, and McCoy walks us through this process and how to actually get social media companies to move on the missteps. Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jj_LmFno0ow (5/12)

title: Allen School Colloquium: Pang Wei Koh (Stanford University)

title: Computational Antitrust: Antitrust Agencies’ View (Dorrell, Skácelová, Giménez, Westrik, Groza)

last_post.content: Next was a nice roundtable with different #antitrust agencies' detailing current applications of computational antitrust at the #StanfordCodeX Computational Antitrust Conference with David Dorrell, Romana Skácelová, Daniel Westrik, Gerard Gimenez, and Teodora Groza. Lots of variance in the tools being deployed, and I'm looking forward to seeing how these different multinational agencies collaborate in the future https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HPEqIPay3Pg (3/12) #regulation #law

Highly recommend https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=waiyxVeQ_kI (2/12)

title: REVEALED: Pentagon Psy-Op EXPOSED In Twitter Files | Counter Points

last_post.content:
The new twitter is garbage, and Musk is despicable.

But the old twitter was only less smelly garbage, and the reporting by Lee Fang on how they collaborated with the pentagon to create fake accounts to influence foreign politics is a great example.

Everyone in the US goes bananas when accusing the Russians of doing stuff like this, but when evidence comes of the same thing done by the US — then it's silence.

The underlying reason is clear: most people in the US — republicans and democrats alike — actually think this is justified.
